The Solar System is the Sun and everything that revolves in orbit around it. This includes the nine planets and their moons, asteroids and comets numerous. All are held in orbit around the Sun by the strong gravity of the sun.
In the solar system there are 8 planets; our planet is Earth, next to it there are seven more planets:

Mercury is the smallest planet in the solar system, and is the closest to the sun is. The surface of this planet is much like the "seas" of our Moon, being also very abundant craters. It has begun to be studied in detail at the beginning of the century. Mercury can be seen with the naked eye, but sometimes you may need binoculars to observe.

The second planet, Venus, is known for glowing at dawn or dusk, a feature that has earned him the nickname "star". It\'s a beautiful planet to observe with the naked eye. If you have a telescope and point it get to him, you will find that you can get to show phases like the Moon. This curious phenomenon is that is closer to the Sun than the Earth and so the sunlight can illuminate it from different angles. The temperature of Venus is higher than Mercury, even though it is farther from the sun. An astronomer named Carl Sagan discovered why this mystery, and so we know that this is due to the presence of gases in the atmosphere Venus causes a large greenhouse, retaining the heat they receive from the sun.

The earth is a big ball of rock, slightly flattened at the poles, and that turns around the Sun in 365 days and almost 6 hours. More than 70% of the surface is covered by oceans of liquid water. Earth inhabit millions and millions of living beings and is the site from which we are beginning to know the universe as it is. Only astronauts have managed to see Earth from space, some from orbit, hundreds of kilometers, and others from the moon, hundreds of thousands of kilometers.

Mars is farther from the sun than Earth, and why does there colder. Mars has huge volcanoes, one of them, Mount Olympus, the largest in the solar system. It has frozen on its surface and underground water, as demonstrated by the Phoenix (Phoenix) robot. In the future we may find life on this planet. Mars is clearly visible to the naked eye.

Jupiter is huge as 1,321 Earths. Although the Sun is much larger, of course, as 984 times Jupiter. It is a gas and capable of emitting radio waves planet. Jupiter\'s atmosphere is of enormous complexity, and its study may help us understand better how atmospheric phenomena on Earth and the famous climate change occur. In the atmosphere of Jupiter storms and anticyclones larger whole planet Earth and winds reach speeds unimaginable form. Accompany more than 60 satellites, the most known Io, Europa, Ganymede and Callisto, the four visible with simple binoculars from Earth. Jupiter is perfectly visible to the naked eye.

Saturn always calls attention by the imposing ring around it. Actually not a single ring, but they are several. These rings are compose of millions of pieces of ice, some as big as a building, and other tiny, like a speck of dust. If you are able to find Saturn in the sky (it is observable to the naked eye) and then join up with you can see one of the greatest wonders of nature telescope: the rings of Saturn. Saturn is not the only planet with rings, but it is the one with the most beautiful. All gaseous planets have rings, although it is very difficult to see. And one last curiosity: to be composed mainly of gas and be as large compared to its mass, Saturn would float in the sea, could fit assuming, of course.

Uranus is the first planet discovered with a telescope, by musician and astronomer William Herschel in 1781, although it is true that you can see with the naked eye and certain African tribes had observed long before him. All the planets revolve around an axis, and all axes of all the planets are slightly inclined, but the planet with the axis of rotation is tilted more Uranus, with almost 98 Â°.

Neptune is a beautiful deep blue color and was the first planet discovered with mathematics. It was precisely Le Verrier one who indicated through their mathematical calculations, what would your position in the sky, so that the astronomer Galle discovered it in 1846 with a telescope. In all gaseous planets there are winds of unusual strength, and Neptune, like Jupiter, storms the size of whole planets are formed. Scientists believe that Neptune could have changed its position countless times Uranus million years ago, so it may not have always been the farthest planet from the Sun.

It is one of the Jovian moons or Galilean Jupiter and is the largest in the solar system. Its name comes from a beautiful Trojan prince, son of the eponymous Tros (or Laomedonte, according to sources); Ganymede became the lover of Zeus and the cupbearer of the gods. On the etymology of its name Robert Graves (The Greek Myths) proposes ganuesthai + medea, "rejoicing in virility". This name was popularized from the mid-twentieth century.

It is the largest of Saturn and easily visible with amateur telescopes. The name "Titan" and the other seven satellites known Saturn by John Herschel (son of William Herschel) comes from its publication in 1847 of his observations on Saturn which he suggested the names of the Titans, sisters and brothers of Cronos ( the Greek name for the Roman god of time Saturn) as a more effective method for naming the satellites of Saturn hitherto designated by Roman numerals in the order of proximity to the planet.

The satellite is named after one of the many lovers of Zeus in Greek mythology, where Callisto was a nymph (or, according to other sources, daughter of Lycaon) who was associated with the goddess of hunting Artemis. The name was proposed by astronomer Simon Marius soon after the discovery of the satellite. Marius attributed the suggestion to Johannes Kepler. However, the names of the Galilean satellites fell into disuse for a considerable time and not again extend their use until the mid-twentieth century. In much of the relatively recent astronomical literature, Callisto is quoted by Roman numeral designation, Jupiter IV, a system introduced by Galileo, or as the "fourth satellite of Jupiter"
It is the third Jovian or Galilean moon of Jupiter. Named Io, one of the many maidens with whom Zeus fell in love in Greek mythology.

It is the largest in the Solar System relative to the size of its planet, a quarter the diameter of Earth and 1/81 its mass natural satellite and is the second densest satellite after Io. It is in synchronous relationship with the Earth, always showing the same face to Earth. The visible hemisphere is marked with dark volcanic lunar maria among the bright ancient mountains and astroblemas outstanding.

It was named after Europa, one of the many amorous conquests of Zeus in Greek mythology. Simon Marius suggested the name "Europe" after its discovery, but this name, and the name of the other Galilean moons were not commonly used until the mid-twentieth century. In much of the earlier astronomical literature I is mentioned for its Roman numeral designation, "Jupiter II" or as the "second satellite of Jupiter". It is the smallest of the Jovian or Galilean moons.

The sun is a star. It is a huge sphere of hot gas is shining and turning. much bigger and brighter than other stars because we are very close to him it appears. The Sun is the center of our solar system. All the planets in our solar system, including Earth, revolve around the sun.

The Moon is the satellite of our planet, Earth. satellite is called because revolves around us, and has done so more than four billion years. But where did it come from? For some astronomers think that once was a part of our planet and others who passed through here and came so close to Earth that the force of gravity (the force that the Earth sticking it to her like a magnet and not let us out floating like astronauts) he attracted him and not let him never go further.

A star is a huge sphere of gas very hot and bright. Stars produce their own light and energy through a process called nuclear fusion. The merger happens when the lighter elements are forced to become heavier elements. When this happens, a tremendous amount of energy is created causing the star to heat up and shine. The stars they are found in a variety of sizes and colors. Our sun is a yellow star of average size. The stars that are smaller than our sun are red and which are larger than this are blue.

A constellation is a group of stars that takes an imaginary shape in the night sky. They are usually named after mythological characters, people, animals and objects. In different parts of the world, people have invented different ways for the same groups of bright stars. This is like a game of connect the dots on a sheet of paper. In the past, creating imaginary images of the stars was useful for navigation at night and to follow the course of the seasons.

Spacecraft are vehicles designed to operate beyond the Earth\'s atmosphere, in outer space. There are 2 types of robotic ships are not carrying them crew and remain for a long time in space and are more well known as satellites and crewed ships that are carrying as passengers astronauts. One of the best known is the Orion spacecraft, the Endeavour or Magellan, which were created by NASA and can accommodate up to 6 crew. It is important to know that a spacecraft is divided into several parts, has a kind of nerve system or brain that is what saves the information in its memory, and can transmit it in real time with communication with the base on earth, and which can be commanded by astronauts; also it has antennas which are a kind of satellite that emit waves and is also constituted by the body which is where the crew roost.

Galaxies are huge collections of stars, dust and gas. Usually they contain from several million to more than a trillion stars and can vary in size from a few thousand to several hundred thousand light years across. There are hundreds of billions of galaxies in the universe. Galaxies come in many different sizes, shapes and brilliance, and like the stars, are found alone, in pairs or in larger groups called clusters. Galaxies are divided into three basic types: spiral, elliptical and irregular.
